Subject: Re: [neat] Leaky Integrate-and-Fire Neurons
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=183620858; y=sMCgwWBmDgJTaCyNmAfqq-fxfgzw-hnI-jhKiQj0mPR8zks
X-Yahoo-Profile: blue5432

Hey Cesar,

I guess your friend isn't on this list? Has she actually run any
simple simulations using this implementation? My advisor is a big fan
of Izhikevich, so I'm interested to hear how those are working out.

The thing is, I've actually implemented the networks with LIF neurons
and STDP in Java. I'm at the point where I'm putting the things
together in simple networks, tuning parameters, and actually trying to
figure out how they behave. And I was wondering if anyone else here
had worked with them much.

One issue is how to handle the input of a post-synaptic neuron. In the
models I've looked at, the membrane potential of a given neuron is
represented separately from the action potential it generates upon
spiking. So the neuron has a state (the membrane potential) that is
updated based on input, and once it reaches threshold it fires,
generating output (the action potential), which conforms to an alpha
function. I'm particularly interested in the issue of how to handle
multiple presynaptic action potentials. I believe the alpha functions
are normally multiplied by the connection weights and then summed. But
if a given pre-synaptic neuron's output has not settled to zero by the
time it spikes again, you can get very large outputs that stack up,
even from a single presynaptic neuron, driving the post-synaptic
firing rate very high, which tends to screw up the STDP.

Don't know if any of that made any sense, but these are the sorts of
issues I'm dealing with and wanted someone with some experience to
chat about.

Thanks,
Derek




On Thu, Jun 19, 2008 at 10:20 AM, Cesar G. Miguel <cesar.gomes@...> wrote:
> Derek,
>
> A friend of mine has implemented an InF module (as well as the
> Izhikevich spiking model) for our NEAT Python project. I'm not very
> familiar with them, but she's been working with these models in her
> research.
>
> You can browse the source code of our project here:
> http://code.google.com/p/neat-python/source/browse -- what you want is
> in /trunk/neat/ifnn. The code is a mix of Python and C++, but there is
> a "pure python" version of the InF and some C++ bindings. You can
> easily understand the sources since Python is "almost" like
> pseudo-code :-)
>
> Hope it helps!
>
> Cesar
>
> On Thu, Jun 19, 2008 at 1:45 AM, Derek James <djames@...> wrote:
>> Hey all,
>>
>> I've just recently started working with leaky integrate-and-fire (LIF)
>> neurons, and since I don't have any prior experience with them and I'm
>> relying on written resources, I thought I'd post a quick question here
>> to see if anybody else had done much work with them. I have a few
>> questions regarding their implementation, as well as spike-time
>> dependent plasticity (STDP).
>>
>> We've got almost 400 members now in the group...anybody have any
>> experience implementing these things?
>>
>> Thanks,
>> Derek
>
